summary: Traffic Signal Wrongly Programmed. VERY DANGEROUS!
description:
Wrong assignments of green light priorities.
VERY DANGEROUS!

Scenario:
If I am turning left from Everett St. into Soldiers Field Rd.
1. I see a green left ARROW (meaning I can safely turn left immediately as it lights up)
2. The cars that are coming out of the park's parking lot and proceeding ether straight across Soldiers Field onto Everett ALSO see a green light and start traveling at the same time with me and honking, because they think they have a right of way.

Proper functionality must be:
When in step 1 I see a green ARROW, oncoming traffic must have RED LIGHT, NOT GREEN. Please fix asap!

There needs to be a "No Turn on Red" sign on eastbound Marlboro street as it approaches Berkeley street to protect pedestrians and avoid accidents.  Marlboro street is an eastbound one way street that switches to westbound one way street at the busy Berkeley street intersection.  As a result, there are 3 one way streets coming together.  Many cars take a left on red from eastbound Marlboro onto Berkeley.  The problem is that the are turning left on Red even when cars (that have a green) are turning right.  The problem is worse during rush hour when the two directions of Marlboro compete to turn onto Berkeley and it creates a very dangerous situation for pedestrians that are attempting to cross Berkeley.  Drivers are distracted by the car coming from the opposite direction and are often not looking for pedestrians.  A No Turn On Red sign would help this situation.  I've seen several car-vs-pedestrian near misses at this intersection.

I put in a SeeClickFix # 3311601 because  I stepped in the open tree well back when there were trees in the pits and sprained my ankle. I asked that the city put in the iron covers (grates) , like there are on all the other trees on Summer Street, so that people could walk on the sidewalk and not be injured. Unfortunately the city removed the trees rather than put in well covers. My goal wasn't to have the trees removed, we need more trees in downtown Boston. But be that as it may. Now there are two empty trees pits and the color of the material in the pit is very like the color of the sidewalk so now many people are stepping into the tree pit and potentially hurting their ankles or knees. So can the city either put in new trees and use the iron covers to cover the tree wells, like the other trees on Summer St or fill in the tree pits so that people aren't potential hurting themselves. Thank you.

summary: 3 months of house shaking from trucks hitting incomplete street work on bypass
description:
This issue, post on April 3rd, 2017, hasn't been fixed (https://seeclickfix.com/issues/3312233-house-shaking-from-trucks-hitting-incomplete-street-work-on-bypass-it-isn-t-marked). Road workers come out once or twice at week between 10pm - 4am to do loud noisy work on these metal covers and whatever is underneath them, but they apparently haven't completed their work and haven't re-paved the road.

We're going to be coming up on 3 months of our home shaking with every truck hitting these temporary hole covers at 50 B Street.

I've called Boston:311 5+ times. My neighbors have called Boston:311 several times. Boston:311 keeps saying they'll "look into it" and "it's probably a contractor doing the work".

Take responsibility for your contractors! What on earth could they being doing for three months in these holes?

summary: house shaking from trucks hitting incomplete street work on bypass - it isn't marked
description:
Late last night gigantic equipment started ripping holes in the bypass road in several locations behind our home. Then, trucks started driving over those holes and make loud booming sounds that shake our home. 

We were awoken constantly last night from all the trucks hitting these holes and I've seen no additional work being done today. 

In addition, these holes in at least 5 locations on the bypass road are completely unmarked. Since cars and trucks are constantly speeding down the bypass they don't see the holes coming up and hit them at very high speeds. At the very least you could earn drivers and mark there holes with spray paint. 

Our home has been shaking all day, and I assume the same applies to our neighbors.

Please bring someone out to mark these holes so people at least slow down. 

Here are videos of the trucks hitting the road work: https://goo.gl/photos/Ld9VKb72vstUWJZP9
Large pothole on Parker between Huntington and Ruggles, heading towards Ruggles Street.

The two trees in front of the 5 guys restaurant 58 summer street are missing their iron grates. This makes it hard to walk on the sidewalk because it is very narrow for the amount or people walking their. So you are forced to wait for people walking the other way to walk past or step into the mud around the tree. I unfortunately did this the other day and badly sprained my ankle. The other trees on summer street have the iron grates so can we get these two trees the grates they need so people can use more of the sidewalk  and not hurt themselves. Thank you.
6 cars in the bike lane in front of city hall!

Massive pothole on the left lane right under the Gilmore bridge. Poor lighting and wet weather made it impossible to see. I hit the pot hole last night (4/1) and immediately blew a tire. Pulled into the Shell gas station down the road and found 2 other cars with a blown tire parked there.

Over the course of the next hour to change the tire and pump my spare, another 4-5 cars were also stopped on the road/in the gas station with a flat tire.

A gentleman also came by to ask if I got the flat from the pot hole and told me he also got a flat hours before and witnessed 2 other people with a flat at that time.

The dumpster at the public housing at 71 B Street often has trash blowing out of it and when it gets emptied by the trash trucks, the contents of the dumpster get thrown to the street and blown around. Most of that trash ends up in the front area of 50 B Street, including in the street under the curb and in the sewer drains. It also ends up blowing all the way down Gold Street to the dead end.

We've been putting up with this trash issue for years now and it's not getting any better.

Here's an album of images of the dumpster, street, trash, and a diagram of the flow of trash:
https://goo.gl/photos/mnzE41wUVY7Rjyt79

summary: Other-- Parking enforcement staff walking in street
description:
I nearly hit a parking enforcement officer today. It freaked me out. No, I wasn't texting or distracted, the officer stepped out into traffic without looking. She was wearing a black jacket and in the cloud/dusk was difficult to see. 

If their job requires them to step into traffic or work in the road, perhaps you could equip each with a reflective vest? They're actually required for all roads that were built with federal funds (all in Boston). 

I really hope no officers get hurt, and certainly am glad they didn't today. Why not invest in safety not stealth?

Thanks!

summary: Right turn only conflicts with walk sign
description: When driving west on Milk St towards Washington St one encounters a stop light at Milk and  Washington St.   Normal vehicular traffic can only take a right hand turn on to Washington St when the light is green as it is a T intersection and left hand turns on to Washington St is prohibited.   When the traffic on Milk St has a green light a pedestrian crosswalk sign is illuminated white for pedestrians crossing Washington St at the Old South Meeting House.   This creates a conflict between the pedestrians and the cars on Milk street that are forced to make a right hand only turn.   Given this is and the fact that vehicular traffic is restricted on Washington St heading north is it possible to get this crosswalk sign and traffic lights reconfigured?   Example Washington St traffic heading north could have a blinking yellow when the intersection is theirs and the cross walk sign is illuminated white. Over a year ago, I requested speed humps on Virginia and Monadnock Streets. As I sit here, mopeds are flying up and down the one way roads - often in the wrong direction. This has been a daily occurrence all summer and into the fall. Since posting about this issue in May 2015, I have seen two efforts to solve the problem: 
1. On one afternoon, I saw a cop patrolling the intersection to ticket those who did not stop at the stop sign. Only ONCE in a year and a half have I seen someone enforcing the stop signs. As a stay-at-home mom, we are outside nearly every day, rain or snow or shine, so it is unlikely that  it has been patrolled more often and I just missed it.
2. A sign was hung that reads "Drive Slow" and has a picture of a running child. That's a nice gesture. However, the signs have been entirely ineffective considering the excessive speeding that still occurs at this intersection.

I ask you respectfully to please again consider my request for speed humps which will actually slow the traffic and lead to a safer road for my children and my neighbors' children. Please let me know the procedure on how to obtain these. Do I need a signed petition by neighbors? If so, I know this can happen.

Thank you.
Sincerely,
a concerned mother and neighbor

Motorcycles are always a public nuisance, spewing excessive chemical and noise pollution. Their drivers' propensity to quickly accelerate into any existing gap in the traffic flow means they are especially bad in stop-and-go traffic, which frequently occurs during evening rush hour.  Thus the 7pm Wednesday night concerts are frequently drowned out by the nasty sound of polluting motorcycles accelerating past thousands of people trying to enjoy the nice things our city offers.

Ban motorcycles.

Or if not, ban them from Storrow drive on Wednesday evenings.

on sidewalk near arthur fielder bridge....i was walking on sidewalk on 4th of july in a crowd...women in front of me stutter steps and steps over pothole/uneven pavement...i had no time i being from florida(originally) from stoneham. ma)...I steeped right in pothole andtripped over uneven pavement...resulting in a banged up knee and a severely sprained right wrist...most importantly, my livelihood as a letter carrier is delayed because im out of work for 2 plus weeks,,,,i lived in boston for 20plus years...never went to esplanade..the one time my family and i went i get hurt...we made the best of it, enjoyed the day with NO Alcohol as usual justfun, freedom, and good food and great fireworks and music.....i have pics but i am rigt handed and my right hand is in a splint...i typed this with my left hand....oh by the way the friendly and  cute emts sthat day gave me some awesome tlc.... peace out to all the wicked awesome Emts and police officers who do there job well....now lets make those public safety workers do the same..Fix those potholes so boston can once again be a safe walking city i do remember

The solid and dashed lane markings that once marked a bike lane on Cambridge Street and Washington Street are in very bad shape after the winter. As a result drivers are trying to cram two lanes of traffic into one lane, causing more congestion and making it hazardous for cyclists trying to ride where the bike lane used to be. Both Boston and Somerville need to restripe their segments of Cambridge/Washington, but Boston's is in much worse condition.

I purchased Boston Meter Cards that previously were extremely useful. Now, with parking meters throughout the city having been replaced by new credit-card-reading individual units or multi-space ticket machines, my cards that still have value are useless. How can I get the money left on them refunded to me? I paid for these cards with the expectation that I would be able to use them to pay for parking, and now that I can't, I believe it's only fair that I receive a refund on the unused value. Before all of the meters were replaced, the cards were (and, I assume, still are) functioning properly. Thank you.

This isn't about a traffic signal, but rather about people obeying the signal.  I cross the intersection of Washington St. and the Arborway as a pedestrian almost daily, and every single time, there is someone blowing through the crosswalk while pedestrians have a walk signal.  People will not stop doing this until they are held accountable.  I would like there to be a camera monitoring the intersection and taking pictures of violators in order to ticket them.  Police presence is not the answer, as it will only momentarily deter the behavior during the police presence.  Furthermore, traffic is already congested there, and police pulling people over on the Arborway, where there is no shoulder, would cause traffic to become a nightmare.  I know fines are a regressive system, but I would like to point out that, in my experience, the most flagrant violators are white people in nice cars.

I live on the corner of this intersection and I have for two years. On average I hear 4 accidents a week at this corner, and that's just when I am home. It's a problem with the middle and right lane when getting off Storrow Drive at the Kenmore exit. The middle lane can turn right, and the right lane is Right Turn Only, but there's only one little sign under the tree saying that. What happens is when the middle lane turns right, but someone in the right lane goes straight and they collide. This happens so often and I have reported it to the city of Boston many times. It's a simple fix - the lanes actually need to be painted with arrows and that would fix this very redundant problem!

summary: metal plates are slippery when wet or icy
description: The metal plates at the guard booth are extremely slippery when wet or icy, posing a hazard to bicyclists.  This connection to 1st Ave in Charlestown is a busy bicycle commuter route since it connects important employment sites in the Navy Yard to Boston and Cambridge.  It is used by hundreds of cyclists per day.  I recently almost slipped and fell off my bike while traveling over the large metal plate.  An abrasive surface treatment or appropriate paint could mitigate this problem.

summary: Bicycle racks needed near Boston Common
description: There is a severe shortage of bicycle racks around Boston Common.  This is a busy area and near several important transit stations.  There is plenty of space along Boston Common to install racks, especially along Tremont Street.  Right now bikes end up being locked to street signs, including handicapped signs, where the bikes could obstruct vehicle access for people in wheelchairs, etc.  Let's install racks where the bikes can be stored properly and safely.

summary: What do I do with my old Boston Meter Cards that still have value?
description: A few years ago, when the City of Boston introduced the new Boston Meter Card smart cards, I purchased a handful of them worth several hundred dollars. Now, with parking meters throughout the city having been replaced by new credit-card-reading individual units or multi-space ticket machines, my remaining cards that still have value are useless. How can I get the money left on them refunded to me? I paid for these cards with the expectation that I would be able to use them to pay for parking, and now that I can't, I believe it's only fair that I receive a refund on the unused value. Before all of the meters were replaced, the cards were (and, I assume, still are) functioning properly. Thank you.

As of 12/3/15, now that 2 lanes are available again to go from the Harvard Business School over Storrow/Soldiers Field and onto the Anderson Memorial Bridge, the multiple signs along the road that say "Right lane must turn right" are conflicting with the arrows painted on the road that indicate that the right lane may either turn right OR go straight. Someone seeing the signs will get into the left lane to go straight over the bridge, then get stuck behind left-turning cars while the right lane passes them and goes straight over the bridge. Conflicting signs increase the chance of an accident. The signs along the right side of the road that say "Right lane must turn right"  should be covered up or removed (it is better for the left lane to be for left turns and the right lane to have the option to go straight).

Today there was a rollover at the corner of Bird, Virginia, and Monadnock Streets due to a speeding driver. Although there are two stop signs on Bird St as cars enter Virginia and Monadnock, drivers continually ignore the signs and cops are rarely seen enforcing them. In the warmer weather, mopeds speed through this intersection, often travelling the wrong way down the one way roads. There is a daycare on this corner and parents park on the street and carry their babies into the building. There are also at least four homes in this intersection where toddlers and young children live. At the very least, there should be speed humps installed to help slow down the traffic. These roads are one way and entirety residential, so theoretically drivers would be careful and traffic minimal. However, with the ongoing construction on Columbia road, more and more drivers have begun using Virginia and Monadnock as shortcuts to avoid traffic on the main road. Speeding vehicles has become a major problem. Please do something to help before a tragedy occurs.

The area is near 34 Westview St, Dorchester, MA. I writing to report a hazardous snow mound behind the Joseph Lee school. As the two Pike exits merge together and then again merge onto Cambridge St, there are no signs indicating the merges. The new bike lane further complicated things as it is unclear whether the lane shifts or ends where the bike lane begins. In at least two places, lanes simply end. Signs warning of the merge / indicating right of way / displaying merged lane patterns are arguably a necessity for avoiding future accidents.  Additionally, re-painting of the road lines is sorely needed (this should have been done when the bike lane was added, which itself already needs re-painting in many areas).  Overall this whole area from merging off of the Pike exits, thru the first couple stop lights after that on Cambridge St, is very poorly marked for cars and bikes alike.
The crosswalk here at Lincoln and Cambridge has electronic cross/don't cross signs but they do not work for some reason.

At both crosswalks that cross Lincoln St near this location, cars are frequently parked on the side of the road. It is unclear if parking is even allowed here to begin with -- if yes, it should not be; if no, it needs a sign. It's really hard to see pedestrians, and the road is narrow at these points so parked cars turns it effectively into a one-way street.

From getting off the Pike, until at least the traffic lights at Lincoln Street, what used to be two same-direction travel lanes is now about 1.5 lanes (full right lane and partial left lane) and two-lane travel is extremely hazardous. Have witnessed several near accidents as cars in the left lane swerve into the right lane to avoid jutting snow banks, or generally travel outside their marked lane due to their lane only being partially cleared for long stretches. Either better plowing or a temporary lane closure is needed to avoid an imminent accident.

Litchfield Street and some other side-streets (eg Antwerp) and cross-streets (eg Ascot, Benson, Cygnet) are narrow under *normal* conditions (parking both sides, one travel lane total) and should be permanent one-ways. Now, especially but not exclusively due to all this snow, they can be nearly impossible to navigate as cars coming from both directions face off with nowhere to go. The city should make these streets temporary one-ways until the snow clears -- and even then, consider making them a network of permanent one-ways.

Lincoln Street is narrow under *normal* conditions. With all this snow, Lincoln is now barely 1.5 lanes wide and two-way travel is dangerous if not impossible at some points. The city really needs to consider plowing Lincoln Street to a full 2 lanes, or making it a temporary one-way.  (In fact, somewhat inexplicably, one end of the street, near Soldiers Field road, already *is* an official one-way exit only, although several feet later it turns two-way again for the remainder of the road...)

Not only is it a safety issue to the small children and adults jogging/walking it is also a health issue as the dogs defecate through out the park and the dog owner looks away. Below is a picture if signs that are in the  Boston Common. These signs should be posted in all the parking lots just before entering into the parks fenced area. Proper patrolling and ticketing would also be helpful. Please do not wait until a tragedy happens. Today I saw a woman pushing a baby stroller have a large dog sprint across a field and go right to the toddler in the stroller knocking the stroller over with force. Had it not been for the Mother if the toddler who sprawled across her child and stroller and kick the dog away, I would hate to think what could have happened.

I appreciate the new Yawkey station, however it has made one problem much worse: Most of the passengers who use the stairs from the station to Beacon St must cross Beacon, and there are no crosswalks at this location. The crosswalk does not need to be substantial, and the passengers using the stairs do not require handicapped accessible accommodations, however there should be a crosswalk at this location. Ideally this crosswalk would connect somewhere between the stairs from Yawkey station, and the stairs to Blanford Mall at Boston University. This is a path that is used by a large percentage of the rail passengers, and the current conditions are unsafe. 

If this is not the appropriate outlet for this request, please let me know who I should contact to get a crosswalk installed at this location.

The intersection of the SW Corridor Park, Tremont St., and Malcolm X Blvd is very bad.  There are 8 lanes of traffic coming from 4 different directions to pay attention to, and the crosswalk is the old-fashioned kind that gives no acknowledgement when the button is pressed.  Everybody assumes the pedestrian cross request button doesn't work, so nobody ever pushes it, and as a result, pedestrians and bicycles both ignore the light and cross whenever the feel they can.  I commute the SW Corridor by bike every day and I can't even count the number of near disasters I've seen at this intersection.  It would be dramatically improved if the new crosswalk buttons that have a light and audible confirmation when pressed were installed here.  I have noticed that pedestrians and bicyclists are far more inclined to wait for the light at intersections where these devices are used.

The bike lane heading northbound on Mass Ave alongside the Christian Science Plaza is completely torn up.  It is in much worse condition than the street, but bicyclists who ride in the street (to avoid the potholes, gravel, cracks, and sand in the bike lane) are cursed at and crowded by drivers who think the bicycles should be in the bike lane.  You would need a full suspension mountain bike to comfortably ride in this lane.  I understand that repaving probably won't be possible until the spring, but at that point, fixing this section of bike lane should be a top priority for the city.

I live in the 12th FLOOR of a dorm building located in the Boylston and Tremont intersection. My dorm is called the Little Building, and it is literally right across the street from an insanely loud beeping intersection box. I understand it's a help to the blind, but it beeps all during the night. I don't think I've even heard it during the day. Maybe the hours are flipped, but something's wrong. I am on the top floor of my building, and still the noise is far too loud. The students in my dorm all can't sleep, and we would greatly appreciate it if there were a time it could be shut off so we could sleep. This is a recent issue, also. 9pm to 11am would be ideal!!!

summary: Need painted lines on street for safety
description: Both the double yellow and dotted white lines in the street on Hyde Park Ave are entirely faded. Because this area is so congested (T, buses, park and ride lot, double parking at businesses, pedestrians crossing without a walk sign), this is a significant safety concern. Cars often ride in between the two lanes because there is no clear delineation. This is a pretty simple and cheap fix that would help traffic move much more smoothly and safely.

summary: Illegal and Inattentive driving on the Jamaicaway.
description:
Just today, from 9:30 am to 10:30, I witnessed an illegal left hand turn at Burroughs Street, a car running a red light - not even close, the light had turned red before the said driver arrived in the intersection.   Drivers on cell phones and not being attentive on this narrow stretch of dangerous roadway, going over the double line.  Speeding is commonplace.
We need policing, if there was some visible police presence, the problems might alleviated, rather than having lives shattered as we just experienced recently.  Please do something.

the traffic lights on L & Columbia rd & Day Blvd are outdated & dangerous. the blinking traffic lights that have been used for the past 30 plus years are not keeping up with the increase in car traffic that this area has seen as a short cut for South Shore commuters. Cars don't even stop for the solid red and yellow lights. they just drive right through them. There are a lot of near miss collisions as cars ease out to try and turn from L onto Day as the lights blink.

I never see police presence, and I live right in this area. Please police this area!    Thank you.

summary: Missing "bicycles may use full lane" signs
description:
The road over the Charlestown Bridge (N. Washington St. which then becomes Rutherford Ave) would benefit from "Bicycles may use full lane" signs in both directions. See Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices, sign R4-11. 

Experienced cyclists on this stretch of road already use the full lane and a formal sign notifying motorists would be helpful. Inexperienced cyclists either hug the edge in what becomes a truly dangerous maneuver on the bridge or they illegally and awkwardly squeeze past pedestrians on the sidewalk (which currently has scaffolding on one side during construction work, and heavy pedestrian traffic at times on both sides).

This is not a re-design. It is a sufficiently clear-cut case that it just seems like an oversight to be handled by a replacement of signs that should have been there in the first place.

summary: Crosswalk timing is incredibly short, most pedestrians jaywalk
description: The walk timer at this intersection (crossing A st while on Congress) is about 10 seconds long and only comes up every 3-4 minutes.  This leads most pedestrians to get frustrated and cross when they don't have the light, but this can be a dangerous intersection with lots of traffic turning that may not see pedestrians.  I've seen several people practically get hit here in the last few months.  Better pedestrian right of way would go a long way to making this a safer intersection for drivers and pedestrians.

Parents who drop their children off at 65 Harvard st. are being told by the facility that the bike lane is a dropoff point in front of the building, when there are clearly signs that read NO STOPPING. Traffic along this stretch is heavy and fast and includes many large trucks. Any parking in the bike lane in this area should be given no quarter. Please assign a patrol to routinely scan this area during rush hour, when the issue is most dire.

The result is an immense backup of traffic past the Art Museum almost all the way back to Mass Ave, trying to go west.  The result is also a 15 backup to literally go 1 city block.  PLEASE reset these traffic lights to allow a longer flow of traffic westbound on Huntington Ave.

summary: Housing available in Allston on B Line

Hi, my roommates and I have a nice spot on Commonwealth Ave right on the Green Line (B line) at Allston St. We've got three couches, a spare bed, and an air mattress. We've got a bath/shower, laundry in the basement, plenty of food to share, and I just learned how to make a mean Moscow Mule if that's your sort of thing. We don't have any pets or anything so no worries about allergies. Please let us know if you need a spot. Peace,

-Laura Jane

summary: No plowing in alley 420 despite 6 calls to Mayor's hotline

Location of Public Alley 420 is between and parallel to Beacon and Marlborough Streets, running from Berkeley to Clarendon Street. Location shown on map is incorrect.

summary: need help to clear parking lot.
description:
live on chestnut avenue in JP. My fiancé is a co-owner of a parking lot on chestnut avenue near biltmore street. One of the owners lives out of state and the other two don't offer to help shovel/snow plow at all or to pay someone to do it.  There is limited communication about this lot, despite our many attempts to come up with a plan for how to maintain and improve the lot, which many consider free off street parking.  Two winters ago, we had multiple storms. My fiancé, one or two neighbors and I removed the snow. I was amazed by the lack of interest in helping to remove snow from what is being used as a community parking lot. 

Once this lot was purchased, it was our hope to be able to resurface this lot so that we could get a snow plow in it.  See, there is rock jutting up in the middle if the lot that would damage the snow plow. That option is out.

My fiancé purchased a snow blower with one other owner who never once helped clear the snow from the lot after multiple storms two years ago.

Now I have a horrible cold and my fiancé strained his back yesterday.  We are at a loss about what to do. No one made any effort to shovel the lot yesterday. This apathy makes me sad. With so many social activists in JP, it is shocking what people take for granted-not even picking up a finger to help do anything but clear out their own cars after the "hard" work has been done by others. In my opinion, anyone who uses this lot should feel obligated to help us shovel the lot. 

If the lot isn't cleared, I will not be able to do my job on Monday--I need to visit elderly clients in their homes. Hopefully, I will feel better today, but I cannot see doing the whole job by myself. I think my upstairs neighbor will help, as he did Two winters ago. But, what about all the so-called "community" members who use this lot. Two years ago before jp patch, I had nowhere to voice this opinion. Thank you for creating this forum. 

Anyway, again my fiancé has a back injury and cannot shovel of use our snow blower. I am sick with a cold, feeling weak, sneezing tons and can do some shoveling, but I am not feeling extremely strong to shovel heavy snow after a very cold night by myself-especially the amount needed.  Is there anyone out there who wants to help?  We would grately  appreciate it. If so, email me at vrhargrove7@gmail.com.  I will also contact neighbors for neighbors but that is mostly meant for elderly and disabled people. 

I eagerly await some replies.

Vanessa

Westbound Cambridge Street gets an exclusive left turn arrow at North Harvard Street, even though there's no way to turn left into the closed chain link fence.  This wastes time and gas for eastbound drivers.

summary: MBTA Bus Stop Includes Commercial Driveway
description: The north bound bus stop starts in what appears to be a parking space, crosses an active driveway to a residential and commercial building, and then stretches  a bus length along the curb. Ahead of the bus stop, north on Dorchester Ave., are two public parking spaces. The MBTA needs to move the bus stop forward a car space or two so that the bus stop does not cross the driveway.

Cars do not yield to pedestrians in the crosswalk. Those that do have other vehicles whip around them and almost hit pedestrians. This happens regulary. There is speeding, cars running red lights as well as not stopping for pedestrians in the crosswalk on a regular basis. This happens up and down Day Blvd with no traffic enforcement in sight.

This curb cut is already on a hill, which makes it even more too steep than it would have been. I can't get up it in my wheelchair. Ordinarily I go up steep slopes at an angle, but it's too narrow and cracked, so I walk in the road across the bridge, but I'd rather not.

summary: Need bike lanes in front of state house and around park
Please repair all sidewalks and road.
description:
Hello,  

Please repair and resurface these sidewalks.  Also, will this street be paved soon? Reported earlier this year. Many potholes.  Thank you.

As someone who lives in this neighborhood and drives through this intersection daily, it is very unclear at this intersection which cars are supposed to stop and which aren't.  Right now there is only one stop sign at the bottom of Nottinghill Rd.  It's also very difficult to see the cars coming from other directions because of the way the streets intersect.  It would be really helpful to have a 4-way stop here.

The traffic and walk/don't walk signals are out of synch at times, particularly at night.  When waiting to cross Boylston St. on foot, we wait until the traffic light for the Boylston traffic turns red, and then (ideally) the walk signal turns green.  However, when the longwood area-bound side turns red, the other direction does not always turn red, so it creates an extremely dangerous situation because pedestrians often start crossing at the sight of a red light for the longwood-bound traffic, not realizing that the opposite direction traffic light is still green

Please fix this for a more permanent solution.

summary: Please shovel out my car when it snows and the sidewalk in front of the house.
description: My car is parked in front of my house. It is a 2011 Navy Blue Subaru Legacy Sedan (plate 625JS6). I live at 14 John A. Andrew Street in Jamaica Plain. If you could also shovel the side walk in front of the house, I would greatly appreciate it. I do not know how much snow will accumulate tomorrow so I may not need your services. But you can determine if there is enough snow to warrant shoveling.

My car is a 92 Oldsmobile Cutlass Ciera Station wagon light blue with wood trim.  I'll need the car cleaned and the space dug out, especially the back after the plow goes through!
I have arthritis in my knees and wear an oxygen tank.  I also have chrinic back pain due to a car accident over 11 yers ago.

Hi Joe
I thought you moved to Washington last year?

I am at work and got your email today about shoveling, it can't come at a better time!  But this year has so far been nothing like last year!

You state that people will need to write in to request shoveling each time.  I am sure you know that may be a problem for many people who do not have computers at home.  I finally bought a laptop, but do not have internet connection so I could never do this every time that I need shoveling. 

You were such a HUGE help to me last winter, I could not have made it through without you and your group!  I am now 60 and I need it more this winter than last, as I had r shoulder surgery 6 months ago and am still doing PT and am in more pain than I was before the operation.  I cannot do any shoveling this year.

What can I (and other people who have no internet access) do when we need shoveling?

thanks so much Patty Hall  7 Weld Hill St, JP
617-983-2938

The "carriage lane" on the Roslindale side of the West Roxbury Parkway, between Beech Street and Washington Street, is in terrible shape.  For years the BPW trucks have come through and patched potholes here and there, usually over and over again, but the road is in need of a restart / complete resurfacing.  The "band aid" approach is not working, and the road conditions are starting to get dangerous.  Related comment:  the sidewalks in this part of the parkway neighborhood are a ridiculous mish-mash of cement (nice, but increasingly rare) and blacktop (ugly and do not last nearly as well/long as cement).  See, e.g., the recent sidewalk "repairs" at the corner of Eastbourne and the West Rox Pkwy, which ripped out an uneven section of blacktopped sidewalk and replaced it with an amatuer-ish (at best) section of new blacktop sidewalk.  What a waste of time and money.
"one way" and "do not enter" signs pointing different directions. potentially very dangerous. highly likely a prank.

summary: Resident parking and parking laws in general (not parking within 20 feet of intersection, no parking in crosswalk) not being enforced
description: Resident parking is not being enforced for overnight parking on Medford Street. Those who have resident stickers are being forced to park a number of blocks from our home due to those illegally parking in our spots. I parked 4 blocks from my house after 10pm the other night, and counted 10 cars on my way home, that did not have resident parking stickers. This problem will get worse in the winter, as Terminal street and the Navy yard are the only available parking for those of us on Medford St.The Navy Yard garage has limited space, and Terminal st--which used to be open for parking--is full all the time, and residents are forced to park in "no parking" zones in front of Little Mystic Access Area. Both sides of street need to be opened for parking and "no parking" spaces need to be opened up. many people on the side streets of Elm are parking on Medford and leaving cars all week, keeping us from parking even within a block of our home, when we used to be able to park somewhere close to the front.

Has the issue of sidewalk parking by scooters been addressed?  I was assessed a $65 ticket for parking on the sidewalk.  While other unlicensed scooters were not assessed, the fact that I have properly licensed my bike encouraged ticketing.  While ridership increases, to the great benefit of the city, reasonable parking options are not  widely available.  Is this topic earnestly under discussion?  Are there plans to expand beyond the single area in Back Bay currently serving as the lone beacon of sense regarding this issue?  I would like to be able to keep riding, keeping costs down and helping to alleviate traffic.  All I ask is that I can park near work with a price tag commiserate with my vehicular impact, and not risk an outrageously priced parking violation.  Thank you.

summary: DEEP POTHOLE - could KILL a bicyclist!
description:
On the northeast corner of Sparhawk and Market Streets, across the street from the church, is a small diameter but deep pothole, probably 10 inches or so diameter (relatively round, but it looks like it goes down at least a foot).

A car might be able to drive over this without incident, but given its size, and location (toward the side of the road where bikes stay), a bicyclist (such as myself, who uses this road daily) could easily be thrown off the bike by riding over it accidentally, and die... or survive the fall, get run over and then die... neither option is appealing.

Please inspect and repair asap. Thanks a bunch! I will also call the hotline.

Please install traffic cameras and start punishing people, before someone gets hurt or killed at this intersection.
Thanks,
Marie

However, it often happens that none of these pedestrians bother to press the walk button, so the walk cycle gets skipped and pedestrians cross in between traffic rather than wait for an entire additional walk cycle. The walk cycle should automatically happen between the hours of 6am and 7pm since there is always someone wanting to cross. Can't they control this automatically

summary: Fence fallen, laying across basketball court
description: The fence alongside this side of the American Legion Park fell days ago and is laying across the basketball court. Children playing on the court often have to chase their balls into the street, dodging traffic, while some are riding their bikes over the fallen fence. It's a total mess, incredibly dangerous, and needs to be fixed as soon as possible.

summary: Many cars run the red here to make illegal right turns
description: There is a nice sign telling drivers that they cannot make a right on red at this intersection.  However, many of them do, including MBTA buses, which then conflict with the pedestrian walk sign.  You have many strollers, pedestrians, young children, cyclists, and so forth trying to cross to and from the Commons, who assume that a walk sign means it is safe to walk.  Instead these cars almost run them over and cause them to miss the walk signal; by the time the line of 5-6 cars finally get through the illegal right hand turn, the don't walk signal is back up.

summary: UPS Delivery Driver Parks Illegally DAILY, endangering cyclists.
description: Every morning at about 9:10am, and possibly again throughout the day, a UPS Delivery Van parks in front of the Harvard Stadium Murr Center Gate and completely blocks the bike lane for an extended period of time. This is an EXTREMELY dangerous causeway, with large trucks routinely traveling at over 30mph. This area also has a high volume of cyclists throughout the day. The UPS driver has no reason to use this spot, as there is an access gate only 500 feet further southwest that would allow him access to the buildings on this compound. Negligence and laziness on the part of the UPS company and the Harvard Parking Authority could lead to severe consequences for some innocent commuters.

A few years ago, Boston added a left turn lane from Mass Ave north to Newbury Street west and the Mass Pike ramp.  To line up northbound Mass Ave's two straight-ahead lanes with the lanes on the other side, they added a dashed white line across the intersection to guide traffic to the left.

The line quickly wore away, and now traffic from the left straight-ahead lane goes straight into the right lane on the other side.  This is dangerous, and effectively narrows Mass Ave to one lane in one of its most congested spots.

Boston DPW, please repaint the lane dashes across the intersection right away, and continue to do it each spring.

The pedestrian lights in Kenmore Square show Don't Walk most of the time, even while traffic is stopped.  

This is a waste of time for pedestrians.  It leads to disrespect for the lights.  People ignore them and cross during the Don't Walk, which is dangerous because the light could turn green at any time.

If you want pedestrians to respect the light, the light has to respect pedestrians.

A police car should also be stationed here and pull anyone over who does not stop. There is a sign posted in the middle of the road and I believe it is a $200.00 fine.

summary: Cars Doubled Parked/Using Side Street To Turn Around/Speeding
description:
At the end of the small dead end street (Linley Terrace) cars double park on East Third making it nearly impossible to safely enter and exit this street. Also cars will speed past quickly and nearly hit anyone trying to exit, but cannot see past the double parked cars. 

Also, there are children on this street who live and play outdoors. Cars will routinely whip around the corner and onto the street to reverse directions, making a three point turn, and with the summer months coming, I am very afraid of a child being injured.

Even though Southie doesn't have a lot of small children left, there still are some, so please be careful and do not speed.

summary: Misplaced Traffic lights causing horribly confusing intersection
description: At the soldiers field rd off-ramp onto N Harvard St/JFK st, the traffic light placements are misleading. Each day during rush hour cars unfamiliar with the intersection are stopping in the middle of the bridge. Other lanes of traffic with a green light are circling around them, driving on the wrong side of the road and it is most dangerous for the frequent foot-traffic and blindspots coming from the other on/off ramps. If the light is intended to stop traffic in the middle of the bridge, then the timing of the other street lights are wrong because inevitably there are always cars sitting on the middle of the bridge while other rows of traffic are stuck trying to navigate around them. Please move the lights or re-time things to work properly. There is a large accident waiting to happen here.

summary: Turn Cleveland Circle into a Less Confusing Rotary
description: One can clearly see from satellite imagery that Cleveland Circle used to be a true circle or rotary.  From the ground this intersection is extremely confusing and poorly maintained.  Traffic control is dysfunctional as one needs to look out for multiple streets, green lines and bicycles while navigating a poorly marked intersection.  And the lights still go green even when a green line is entering the intersection.  This intersection would be far more functional if it were turned into a rotary with a green or landscaped median.  This would still support the needs of the greenline (assuming it's too expensive to give it a detected right of way (it's own lane or an elevated route).  Even if converting the intersection to a rotary, it would make sense to have traffic lights that go red to prevent vehicles from entering when a greenline train is entering.

summary: Add Dynamic LED Lane Markings to Reduce Confusion in Kenmore Square
description:
It would greatly improve safety, reduce confusion, and reduce congestion if the city were to add dynamic lane markings embedded into the roadway in Kenmore Square.  As the traffic lights change, LEDs embedded in the roadway could illuminate the proper lane markings for the appropriate pattern(s) of traffic.  Intersections like Kenmore can be confusing, especially to out of towners.  Even if people figure out where to go they often slow down or stop in the intersection to figure it out.  Traditional lane markings or dotted lines wouldn't work here given the density and the number of possible traffic patterns, so LED lane markings that change with the traffic lights would make a lot of sense here.

This shouldn't require the road to be dug up as it's aesthetically in good shape right now.  A blades-width of cutting and filler could accommodate the wiring and a few recesses to accommodate LED pods should be all that's needed.

summary: Put a Stop Line on Maverick Street at the intersection with Bremen Street
description: Drivers continually blow through this stop sign since there is no "stop line" on the street.
